field_description.processed:
What constitutes being human? What are the boundaries or fuzzy edges of humanity? What can we learn from exploring the margins of humanity? These questions lie at the heart of this symposium, which will bring together twelve scholars across a variety of fields to consider how concepts analogous to our contemporary idea of “the human” were defined and debated in Medieval China.

We hope that the papers assembled for the symposium will open new, interdisciplinary vistas on the ways in which ethnocultural others, sociological underclasses, striking and different individuals, animals and gods, and ex- and future-humans were conceptualized and written about in the medieval period, and on the ways in which these marginal beings expressed and challenged the self-understandings of the authors of the materials that survive to us.

The symposium will be held via Zoom from 10am to 1pm, EST, on June 1st through June 3rd, 2022. Registration is free and open to the public.

A special thanks to the Council on East Asian Studies at Yale University for the assistance with the symposium organization and to Gustavo Espada of EALC, Harvard University, for building the symposium website. Questions and comments can be directed to the symposium's graduate coordinator, Baiqian Bian, at baiqian.bian@yale.edu, or to the organizers, Luke Bender and Xiaofei Tian.
